email.heading: Rust 101 Lecture Series - 3rd (and last) Lecture

event.text:
Do you hate segfaults? Do you hate C/C++? Do you hate having segfaults in C/C++? Then you’ll want to join us in Huxley 311 to take a first look at Rust - an upcoming systems language developed by Mozilla and used by Google, Microsoft, Facebook, NPM, Figma, Dropbox, the Linux Kernel (the full list is very long).
In this lecture series, we will be exploring the Rust language and its major features, how Rust delivers safe and fast performance as a guarantee, and why Rust is quickly becoming a replacement to C and C++.

email.heading: Reading Group - Alexandros Lattas: Towards Photorealistic Human Avatars – From Scanning to Inference

event.text:
**Abstract:**
Over the last years, many face analysis tasks have accomplished astounding performance, with applications including face generation and 3D face reconstruction from a single "in-the-wild" image. Nevertheless, the challenging task of reconstructing photorealistic human faces from arbitrary images remains an open research problem. By combining resources from the Computer Graphics, Computer Vision and Machine Learning, we are exploring how realistic human avatars can be captured, reconstructed, and animated.
In this talk, we will cover the Light Stage systems and their use as a facial geometry and reflectance apparatus that can create vast datasets of photorealistic meshes and textures and powerful models that can be created using them. Such datasets can be used to create statistical models of facial geometry and appearance that can be fit to “in-the-wild” images. Deep Generative Learning models can also be trained to capture the non-linearities and high-frequency details in facial reflectance. Finally, differentiable rendering methods can be used to optimize such models and fit them to subjects with increased reconstructed detail. These advances enable the fast and seamless reconstruction of human avatars and bring us a step closer to a convincing digital world.
**Profile:**
Alexandros Lattas is a PhD Candidate at the Department of Computing, Imperial College London and a Researcher in Computer Vision at Huawei R&D. He holds an MSc in Advanced Computing from Imperial College London and was previously a Computer Vision Scientist at Facesoft. Alexandros has published in top venues such as CVPR, ECCV and TPAMI.
